prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Detection of CO emission (SG1): In the redshift range of our targets, the CO emission that falls in the ALMA 3mm band is CO(4-3) for galaxies within 3 < z < 4. We choose to observe in the 3mm due to the better transparency and better observing conditions. Since we expect a brighter dust continuum at a higher frequency in the 3mm regime, we extend the upper sideband (USB) to the high-frequency side. Thus, in each case, we will target the CO emission with the lowest spectral window (among four spectral windows) in the lower sideband (LSB). The others 3 spectral windows, one in the LBS and others two in the USB, will be used to detect the continuum. Assuming a typical linewidth of 400 km/s, a spectral resolution of 100 km/s will be enough for our purposes. Therefore, we use the lowest resolution FDM correlator set-up offered for Cycle 2 (976.6 kHz, ~2.6km/s) and will further bin the data offline to the desired velocity resolution. Standard calibrations will be used for amplitude, gain, pointing and bandpass. Since we are using Band 3, we expect to have nearby calibrators for all these. Finally, we have used the best-fitted CE01 templates for the galaxies proposed to be observed to obtain the expected fluxes in the ALMA 3mm window with the aim of establishing the flux sensitivity required for our observations: 0.15 mJy for a 5 sigma detection. Sources are point-like (no ACA needed), and we adopt a 1" resolution with the 12-m Array

We intend to observe in Band 7 the continuum dust emission of a pair of LAEs at redshifts z~2.6 that lie within the 10 deg limit for a single SciGoal. The sources are expected to be point-like, so we have opted for a 1" resolution with the 12-m Array (no ACA observations required). The sensitivity requirements come from measurements of the UV continuum slope and assuming the Meurer et al (1999, ApJ, 521, 64) and SED fits to estimate a required Band 7 RMS of 20microJy (1sigma) per target to achieve a detection level (5 sigma) of 0.1 mJy

Detection of CO emission (SG1): In the redshift range of our targets, the CO emission that falls in the ALMA 3mm band is CO(3-2) for galaxies within 2 < z < 3. We choose to observe in the 3mm due to the better transparency and better observing conditions. Since we expect a brighter dust continuum at a higher frequency in the 3mm regime, we extend the upper sideband (USB) to the high-frequency side. Thus, in each case, we will target the CO emission with the lowest spectral window (among four spectral windows) in the lower sideband (LSB). The others 3 spectral windows, one in the LBS and others two in the USB, will be used to detect the continuum. Assuming a typical linewidth of 400 km/s, a spectral resolution of 100 km/s will be enough for our purposes. Therefore, we use the lowest resolution FDM correlator set-up offered for Cycle 2 (976.6 kHz, ~2.6km/s) and will further bin the data offline to the desired velocity resolution. Standard calibrations will be used for amplitude, gain, pointing and bandpass. Since we are using Band 3, we expect to have nearby calibrators for all these. Finally, we have used the best-fitted CE01 templates for the galaxies proposed to be observed to obtain the expected fluxes in the ALMA 3mm window with the aim of establishing the flux sensitivity required for our observations: 0.15 mJy for a 5 sigma detection. Sources are point-like (no ACA needed), and we adopt a 1" resolution with the 12-m Array

Detection of CO emission (SG1): In the redshift range of our targets, the CO emission that falls in the ALMA 3mm band is CO(3-2) for galaxies within 2 < z < 3. We choose to observe in the 3mm due to the better transparency and better observing conditions. Since we expect a brighter dust continuum at a higher frequency in the 3mm regime, we extend the upper sideband (USB) to the high-frequency side. Thus, in each case, we will target the CO emission with the lowest spectral window (among four spectral windows) in the lower sideband (LSB). The others 3 spectral windows, one in the LBS and others two in the USB, will be used to detect the continuum. Assuming a typical linewidth of 400 km/s, a spectral resolution of 100 km/s will be enough for our purposes. Therefore, we use the lowest resolution FDM correlator set-up offered for Cycle 2 (976.6 kHz, ~2.6km/s) and will further bin the data offline to the desired velocity resolution. Standard calibrations will be used for amplitude, gain, pointing and bandpass. Since we are using Band 3, we expect to have nearby calibrators for all these. Finally, we have used the best-fitted CE01 templates for the galaxies proposed to be observed to obtain the expected fluxes in the ALMA 3mm window with the aim of establishing the flux sensitivity required for our observations: 0.15 mJy for a 5 sigma detection. Sources are point-like (no ACA needed), and we adopt a 1" resolution with the 12-m Array

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Lyman-alpha emitters (LAEs) are the key sources that have been traditionally employed to study galaxy formation and evolution. However, so far, there is no work in the literature where molecular gas properties of LAEs at any redshift has been reported. This is mainly due to the fact that all previous attempts have been focused on very high-redshift LAEs with low probability of detection. In this proposal we aim at robustly detecting for the very first time the CO of non-lensed LAEs by focusing on Herschel-detected sources. Additionally, we aim at studying the dust emission of typical FIR-undetected LAEs, now possible with ALMA capabilities. This will enable to determine important and still completely unknown properties of LAEs such as molecular gas content, star formation efficiencies, gas depletion times, or stellar-to-molecular, molecular-to-dust, and stellar-to-dust mass ratios. Furthermore, the success of the observations will set a baseline for further studies of molecular gas in more common, IR-fainter high-redshift LAEs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Research Division, Astrophysical Institute of Canarias
Research Division, Astrophysical Institute of Canarias
